module.p:
When gu governs an infinitive (verbal noun), and is itself the predicate of the verb bi, it can mark prospective aspect – about to / on the point/verge of / almost –
Bha Raonaid ... Rachel was ...
... gu gnogadh air an doras. ... about to knock on the door.
... gu snàmh anns an abhainn. ... about to swim in the river.
... gu tuiteam. ... about to fall.
... gu seòladh dhachaigh. ... about to sail home.

Intransitive examples from dictionaries and grammars –
Tha sinn gu falbh.
We’re (just) about to go. td. 220
Bha e gu toirt thairis.
He was on the point of giving up. td. 347 Thug e thairis. He tired himself out.
Bha i gu fannachadh leis an teas.
She was almost fainting with the heat. td. 347
Tha mi gu spreadhadh.
I am almost bursting (with food). td. 161
Tha e gu bristeadh.
It is about to break. td. 161

Intransitive corpus examples –
Ach fuirichibh oirbh, naidheachd ùr á ASTRAILIA. Tha na caoraich a nis a’ faotainn “perm”, mun teid an rùsgadh. [...] Ma bha gearain air cuid de na fir, mu chosg perm nam mnatha, ’s ann a tha an là gu thighinn orra nuair a dh’fheumas na caoraich iad.
But wait – breaking news from Australia. The sheep are getting “perms” now, before they are shorn. [...] If some of the menfolk had complaints about the cost of their wives’ perms, the day is about to come [upon them] when the sheep will need them [too].’ td. 355
Nan robh an latha air a dhol leis an riaghaltas an Dun-Eideann chan eil teagamh nach robh iad air a’ Ghaidhealtachd ’s a’ Ghàidhlig a sgrios gu tur, ’s cha bhiodh air fhàgail ach ainmean-àiteachan troimh ’n deanadh na h-àil ri teachd tuairmeas air an eachdraidh. [...] B’ ann mar sin a thachair an Arcaibh agus an Sealtainn agus chan eil air fhàgail ach cànan is litreachas nam Faroes gu taobh na fìrinn a ghleidheadh. Ach cha robh e gu tachairt sa’ Ghaidhealtachd airson trì cheud bliadhna eile.
If the government in Edinburgh had won the day, they would undoubtedly have completely destroyed the Highlands and the Gaelic, and only place names would have been left for future generations to speculate about their history. [...] That is what happened in Orkney and Shetland and there is nothing left but the language and literature of the Faroes to support the truth. But that was not to happen in the Highlands for another three hundred years. td. 125
Nuair a bha a’ chòmhrag seachad, fhuair Galatea òrdugh a dhol air ais gu Portsmouth, ach on a bha an dìon a bh’ air Caolas Dhòbhair air a lagachadh, bhiodh e iomchaidh a cur timcheall ceann a tuath Alba, sìos an cuan Sgìth, agus troimh ’n Chuan Eireannach. Cha robh Torcuil air a bhean no an leanabh fhaicinn o chionn seachd bliadhna, agus nuair a thuig e far an robh iad gu seòladh, bha e ’na thoileachas dha gum biodh dùil aige ri sealladh fhaighinn do Loch Odhairn agus baile Ghrabhair.
When the battle was over, Galatea was ordered to return to Portsmouth, but since the defence of the Strait of Dover had been weakened, it would be preferable to take her around the northern end of Scotland, down the Minch and through the Irish Sea. Torquil had not seen his wife or their child for seven years, and when he realised where they were to sail, he was pleased that he could hope to see Loch Odhairn and the village of Gravir. td. 348

When the verb is transitive, the form gus is used instead, and the object inverted –
Tha Seumas ... James is ...
... gus (am) biadh ithe. ... about to eat (the) food.
... gus (an) drochaid a ruigsinn. ... about to reach a/the bridge.
... gus (an t-)òran a ghabhail. ... about to sing a/the song.
Nuair a thòisich a’ chlann ri bruidhinn an toiseach bha sinn gus a h-uile oidhirp a dhèanamh agus faclan coigreach a chumail uapa.
When the children started talking at first we were about [ready?] to make every effort to keep the foreign words away from them. td. 345
Bha i gus an t-uan a chur còmhla ri mhàthair a-rithist ach ràin Màiri Bheag cho goirt is nach robh air a’ chùis ach an t-uan a leigeadh air feadh an taighe na fianuis.
She was about to put the lamb together with its mother again but little Mary cried so bitterly that there was no other choice but let the lamb [be] all over the house so that she could see it. td. 81
Tha mi gus mo chiall a chall is gun fios agam ciod e nì mi.
I am about to lose my senses and do not know what I shall do. td. 118
Bha e gus a mhùn a chall ag èisteachd riutha.
He was nearly wetting himself listening to them. td. 220

Examples where gus is used with an intransitive verb –
Tha an tea gus tarraing, is théid mi g’a h-iarraidh dhuibh.
The tea is about to brew and I’ll go to get it for you. td. 199 The tea is about to finish brewing.
Bha e gus tuiteam leis an sgìos agus cha robh e air càil ithe o chionn dà latha.
He was about to collapse with tiredness and he had not eaten anything for two days. td. 46
Ach an cànan ionadail aige fhèin tha e gus bàsachadh. Cànan a bh’ aca san fhàsach bho chionn fhada, ’s chan eil mòran ga bhruidhinn an-diugh.
But his own local language is about to die. A language they had in the desert a long time ago and not many speak it now. td. 157

cf. bi gu bhith ... be about to be ... / be almost/nearly ... –
Tha Màiri gu bhith deiseil. Mary is nearly ready.
Tha an t-uisge gu bhith ann. It’s about to rain.
... mura robh muinntir a’ bhaile gu bhith a’ faighinn buannachd às
... unless the townspeople were to be benefitting from it td. 347 Same as ‘about to be benefitting’?
Tha iad gu bhith deiseil.
They are almost ready. td. 161
cf. Other markers of prospective aspect – an impis, air lunn, air thuar (evidential).
